title: Model fitting and producing short-term forecasts using daily data with EpiEstim
text: vignette provides short demonstration model fitting functions ViroReportR extend functionality wrap estimate_R function EpiEstim package produce short-term forecasts.

title: Model fitting and producing short-term forecasts using daily data with EpiEstim
text: short demonstration, simulate daily data Influenza , RSV Covid-19, using function simulate_data provided ViroReportR package. input dataset must two columns: date confirm accordance format accepted model fitting functions.
code: data <- simulate_data(days=365, #days spanning simulation                       peaks = c("flu_a"=90,"rsv"=110,"sars_cov2"=160), #peak day for each disease                       amplitudes=c("flu_a"=50,"rsv"=40,"sars_cov2"=20), #amplitude of peak for each disease                       scales = c("flu_a"=-0.004,"rsv"=-0.005,"sars_cov2"=-0.001), # spread of peak for each disease                       time_offset = 0, #number of days to offset start of simulation                       noise_sd = 5, #noise term                       start_date = "2024-01-07" #starting day (Sunday)                       ) data$date <- lubridate::ymd(data$date)  vri_data <- data %>%              pivot_longer(cols = -date,  # all columns except 'date'                           names_to = "disease_type",                           values_to = "confirm") # <-- need ot be called confirm  # VRI data set-up vri_name_list <- vri_data %>%      dplyr::group_by(disease_type) %>%    dplyr::group_keys() %>% dplyr::pull()   vri_data_list <- vri_data %>%    dplyr::group_by(disease_type) %>%    dplyr::group_map(~.x)  names(vri_data_list) <- vri_name_list

title: Model fitting and producing short-term forecasts using daily data with EpiEstim
text: code estimates reproduction number using EpiEstim generate_forecast() function disease type via purrr::map2() function. generate_forecast() function prepares data, estimates reproduction number, produces short-term forecasts daily confirmed cases n_days forecast horizon. function supports forecasting SARS-CoV2, RSV Influenza primarily also provides functionality forecast respiratory diseases. respiratory disease can specified setting type = . type = set, user-specified mean_si std_si must passed function well.
code: #parameters set-up start_date <- min(vri_data$date) + 13 forecast_horizon <- 7 smooth <- FALSE validate_window_size <- 7  forecasts_results <- tibble(   vri_data_list,   forecasts = map2(     vri_data_list,     vri_name_list,     ~ generate_forecast(       data = .x,       smooth_data = smooth,       type = .y,       n_days = forecast_horizon,       start_date = start_date     )   ) )  names(forecasts_results$forecasts) <- vri_name_list names(forecasts_results$vri_data_list) <- vri_name_list

title: Model fitting and producing short-term forecasts using daily data with EpiEstim
text: package provides validation functionality support predictive performance evaluation. forecasting model trained historical data used predict daily cases r forecast_horizon days ahead. Validation compares model‚Äôs forecasted values observed historical data, overlap prediction intervals actual cases indicates good model performance. rolling window approach applied historical data generate multiple validation datasets.

title: Model fitting and producing short-term forecasts using daily data with EpiEstim
text: Finally, ViroReportR package can conveniently generate automated report current season supported viral respiratory diseases (Influenza-, RSV SARS-CoV2) using generate_forecast_report function, renders HTML report.
code: tmp_dir <- tempdir()  # Save the simulated data data_path <- file.path(tmp_dir, "simulated_data.csv") write.csv(vri_data, data_path, row.names = FALSE)  output_path <- tempdir() generate_forecast_report(input_dir = data_path,                             output_dir = output_path,                             n_days = 7,                             validate_window_size = 7,                             smooth = TRUE)  cat("Report saved to:", output_path, "\n")  if (interactive() && file.exists(output_path)) {   utils::browseURL(output_path) }

title: Authors and Citation
text: Mike Irvine. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Caesar Wong. Author. Nirupama Tamvada. Author. Rebeca Falcao. Author. Nelson Tang. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Irvine M, Wong C, Tamvada N, Falcao R, Tang N (2026). ViroReportR: Respiratory Viral Infection Forecast Reporting. R package version 1.0.4.9000, https://github.com/BCCDC-PHSA/ViroReportR.
code: @Manual{,   title = {ViroReportR: Respiratory Viral Infection Forecast Reporting},   author = {Mike Irvine and Caesar Wong and Nirupama Tamvada and Rebeca Falcao and Nelson Tang},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 1.0.4.9000},   url = {https://github.com/BCCDC-PHSA/ViroReportR}, }

title: Respiratory Viral Infection Forecast Reporting
text: üìò Documentation website:https://bccdc-phsa.github.io/ViroReportR/ goal ViroReportR provide toolbox conveniently generate short-term forecasts (accompanied diagnostics) viral respiratory diseases.

title: Respiratory Viral Infection Forecast Reporting
text: Install released version CRAN: can install development version ViroReportR GitHub :
code: install.packages("ViroReportR") devtools::install_github("BCCDC-PHSA/ViroReportR")

title: Respiratory Viral Infection Forecast Reporting
text: ViroReportR can used generate short-term forecasts accompanied diagnostics lines code. go example EpiEstim backend used generate forecasts Influenza-, RSV SARS-CoV-2. use simulate_data simulate date Influenza , RSV, SARS-CoV-2, included ViroReportR package. pivot simulated data transform dataset three columns: date, disease_type confirm accordance format accepted model fitting functions.
code: library(ViroReportR) library(tidyverse) #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching core tidyverse packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse 2.0.0 ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> ‚úî dplyr     1.1.4     ‚úî readr     2.1.5 #> ‚úî forcats   1.0.0     ‚úî stringr   1.6.0 #> ‚úî ggplot2   4.0.0     ‚úî tibble    3.2.1 #> ‚úî lubridate 1.9.4     ‚úî tidyr     1.3.1 #> ‚úî purrr     1.0.2      #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> ‚úñ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() #> ‚úñ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag() #> ‚Ñπ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors library(ggplot2) library(here) #> here() starts at C:/Users/rebeca.falcao/ViroReportR library(DT) library(purrr) library(kableExtra) #>  #> Attaching package: 'kableExtra' #>  #> The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr': #>  #>     group_rows diseases<-c("flu_a", "rsv", "sars_cov2") data <- simulate_data(days=365, #days spanning simulation                       peaks = c("flu_a"=90,"rsv"=110,"sars_cov2"=160), #peak day for each disease                       amplitudes=c("flu_a"=50,"rsv"=40,"sars_cov2"=20), #amplitude of peak for each disease                       scales = c("flu_a"=-0.004,"rsv"=-0.005,"sars_cov2"=-0.001), # spread of peak for each disease                       time_offset = 0, #number of days to offset start of simulation                       noise_sd = 5, #noise term                       start_date = "2024-01-07" #starting day (Sunday)                       )  data$date <- lubridate::ymd(data$date)  vri_data_list <- map2(rep(list(data), length(diseases)),   diseases,~ get_aggregated_data(.x, "date", .y)) %>% set_names(diseases)  head(vri_data_list) #> $flu_a #> # A tibble: 366 √ó 2 #>    date       confirm #>    <date>       <dbl> #>  1 2024-01-07       1 #>  2 2024-01-08       0 #>  3 2024-01-09       3 #>  4 2024-01-10       3 #>  5 2024-01-11       0 #>  6 2024-01-12       0 #>  7 2024-01-13       6 #>  8 2024-01-14       0 #>  9 2024-01-15       0 #> 10 2024-01-16       1 #> # ‚Ñπ 356 more rows #>  #> $rsv #> # A tibble: 366 √ó 2 #>    date       confirm #>    <date>       <dbl> #>  1 2024-01-07       0 #>  2 2024-01-08       5 #>  3 2024-01-09       0 #>  4 2024-01-10       0 #>  5 2024-01-11       0 #>  6 2024-01-12       0 #>  7 2024-01-13       6 #>  8 2024-01-14       8 #>  9 2024-01-15       0 #> 10 2024-01-16       0 #> # ‚Ñπ 356 more rows #>  #> $sars_cov2 #> # A tibble: 366 √ó 2 #>    date       confirm #>    <date>       <dbl> #>  1 2024-01-07       0 #>  2 2024-01-08       2 #>  3 2024-01-09       0 #>  4 2024-01-10       4 #>  5 2024-01-11       1 #>  6 2024-01-12       1 #>  7 2024-01-13       3 #>  8 2024-01-14       4 #>  9 2024-01-15       0 #> 10 2024-01-16       2 #> # ‚Ñπ 356 more rows

title: Respiratory Viral Infection Forecast Reporting
text: code estimates reproduction number using EpiEstim generate_forecast() function disease type via purrr::map2() function. generate_forecast() function prepares data, estimates reproduction number, produces short-term forecasts daily confirmed cases n_days forecast horizon. current choice forecasting algorithm EpiFilter (WIP).
code: # parameters set-up  start_date <- min(data$date) + 13 n_days <- 14 # number of days ahead to forecast (n_days) smooth <- FALSE # logical indicating whether smoothing should be applied in the forecast forecasts_results <- tibble(   vri_data_list,   forecasts = map2(     vri_data_list,     diseases,     ~ generate_forecast(       data = .x,       smooth_data = smooth,       type = .y,       n_days = n_days,       start_date = start_date     )   ) )   names(forecasts_results$forecasts) <- diseases names(forecasts_results$vri_data_list) <- diseases

title: Respiratory Viral Infection Forecast Reporting
text: code plots forecasts results estimated RtR_t disease. plot RtR_t, code uses plot_rt function included package.
code: for (vri in diseases) {   forecast_plot <- ggplot() +   geom_ribbon(     data = forecasts_results$forecasts[[vri]][["forecast_res_quantiles"]],     aes(x = date, ymin = p10, ymax = p90, fill = "Prediction Interval"),     alpha = 0.4   ) +   geom_line(     data = forecasts_results$forecasts[[vri]][["forecast_res_quantiles"]],     aes(x = date, y = p50, color = "Median Forecast"),     linewidth = 1   ) +   geom_point(     data = forecasts_results$vri_data_list[[vri]],     aes(x = date, y = confirm, shape = "Positive Tests"),     size = 2,     color = "black"   )  +      labs(     title = paste0(n_days, "-Day Forecast of Daily ", vri, " Positive Tests"),     x = "Date", y = "Predicted Tests",     fill = "", color = "", shape = ""   ) +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("Prediction Interval" = "skyblue")) +   scale_color_manual(values = c("Median Forecast" = "blue")) +   scale_shape_manual(values = c("Positive Tests" = 16)) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "top", legend.direction = "horizontal")      # create Rt plot   rt_plot <- ViroReportR:::plot_rt(forecasts_results$forecasts[[vri]])   print(forecast_plot)   print(rt_plot) }

title: Respiratory Viral Infection Forecast Reporting
text: Finally, ViroReportR package can generate automated report current season across supported respiratory viruses (Influenza , RSV, SARS-CoV-2) using generate_forecast_report() function. function renders HTML report summarizing model outputs forecasts. use , provide input file (input_file) containing required data three columns‚Äîdate, disease_type, confirm‚Äîspecify output directory (output_directory) report saved.
code: # rendering forecast report df <- imap_dfr(vri_data_list, ~ .x %>% mutate(disease_type = .y)) input_file<-"simulated_data.csv" write.csv(df, input_file, row.names = FALSE) generate_forecast_report(   input_data_dir =  input_file, # input filepath   output_dir = output_directory, # output directory   n_days = 14, # number of days to forecast   validate_window_size = 7, # number of days between each validation window   smooth = FALSE, # logical indicating whether smoothing should be applied in the forecast )

what: ViroReportR: Respiratory Viral Infection Forecast Reporting ‚Äî ViroReportR-package
title: ViroReportR: Respiratory Viral Infection Forecast Reporting ‚Äî ViroReportR-package
text: Tools reporting forecasting viral respiratory infections, using case surveillance data. Report generation tools short-term forecasts, validation metrics arbitrary number customizable respiratory viruses. Estimation effective reproduction number based 'EpiEstim' framework described work 'Cori' colleagues. (2013) doi:10.1093/aje/kwt133 .

title: ViroReportR: Respiratory Viral Infection Forecast Reporting ‚Äî ViroReportR-package
text: Maintainer: Mike Irvine mike.irvine@bccdc.ca [copyright holder] Authors: Caesar Wong Nirupama Tamvada Rebeca Falcao Nelson Tang

title: Clean and validate case count data for EpiEstim ‚Äî clean_sample_data
text: Ensures input data frame required columns: "date" "confirm". Confirms specified start_date exists data filters data include records date. Removes leading days first non-zero confirmed case. Verifies resulting dataset contains least 14 valid days (required estimation). function primarily intended preprocessing step EpiEstim modeling. combines validation checks input structure time coverage minimal data cleaning logic ensure robust downstream estimation.

what: fit_epiestim_model - Function to estimate the reproduction number of an epidemic ‚Äî fit_epiestim_model
title: fit_epiestim_model - Function to estimate the reproduction number of an epidemic ‚Äî fit_epiestim_model
text: wrapper function estimate_R EpiEstim library estimate reproduction number epidemics support short-term forecasts

title: fit_epiestim_model - Function to estimate the reproduction number of an epidemic ‚Äî fit_epiestim_model
code: fit_epiestim_model(   data,   window_size = 7L,   type = NULL,   mean_si = NULL,   std_si = NULL,   recon_opt = "match",   method = "parametric_si",   mean_prior = NULL,   std_prior = NULL )

title: fit_epiestim_model - Function to estimate the reproduction number of an epidemic ‚Äî fit_epiestim_model
text: data data frame containing two columns: date confirm (number cases) window_size Integer Length sliding windows used R estimates. type character Specifies type epidemic. Must one "flu_a", "flu_b", "rsv", "sars_cov2" "custom" mean_si Numeric User specification mean parametric serial interval std_si Numeric User specification standard deviation parametric serial interval recon_opt implemented. One "naive" "match" pass estimate_R (see help page) method One "non_parametric_si", "parametric_si", "uncertain_si", "si_from_data" "si_from_sample" pass estimate_R (see help page) mean_prior Numeric positive number giving mean common prior distribution reproduction numbers std_prior Numeric positive number giving standard deviation common prior distribution reproduction numbers

title: fit_epiestim_model - Function to estimate the reproduction number of an epidemic ‚Äî fit_epiestim_model
text: Object class estimate_R (see EpiEstim help page)

title: fit_epiestim_model - Function to estimate the reproduction number of an epidemic ‚Äî fit_epiestim_model
text: fit_epiestim_model currently supports following epidemics: Influenza, RSV COVID-19. default serial intervals estimation R retrieved Cowling et al., 2011, Vink et al., 2014 Madewell et al., 2023 Influenza , Influenza B, RSV COVID (BA.5 Omicron variant) respectively

what: Forecast daily epidemic cases using EpiEstim ‚Äî generate_forecast
title: Forecast daily epidemic cases using EpiEstim ‚Äî generate_forecast
text: function prepares epidemic data, estimates reproduction number (\(R_t\)) using fit_epiestim_model, produces short-term forecasts daily confirmed cases project_epiestim_model. removes early periods cases, checks data validity, optionally smooths epidemic curve, generates forward projections cases specified number days.

title: Forecast daily epidemic cases using EpiEstim ‚Äî generate_forecast
code: generate_forecast(   data,   start_date,   window_size = 7,   n_days = 7,   type = NULL,   smooth_data = FALSE,   smoothing_cutoff = 10,   ... )

title: Forecast daily epidemic cases using EpiEstim ‚Äî generate_forecast
text: data data frame Must contain two columns: date: observation dates confirm: daily confirmed cases start_date Date Date epidemic considered started. Data date removed. window_size Integer Length sliding window (days) used reproduction number estimation. Default 7. n_days Integer Number future days forecast. Default 7. type character Type epidemic. Must one "flu_a", "flu_b", "rsv", "sars_cov2", "custom". Passed fit_epiestim_model. smooth_data logical Whether smooth input daily case counts estimation. Default FALSE. smoothing_cutoff Integer Cutoff parameter smoothing. used smooth_data = TRUE. Default 10. ... Additional arguments passed fit_epiestim_model.

title: Forecast daily epidemic cases using EpiEstim ‚Äî generate_forecast
text: data frame forecasted daily incidence columns: date: date forecast p50, p25, p75, p025, p975: forecast quantiles min_sim, max_sim: forecast range

title: Forecast daily epidemic cases using EpiEstim ‚Äî generate_forecast
text: Data prior first non-zero confirm value excluded. Input checked validity (sufficient days, proper format). smoothing enabled, case counts adjusted fitting. Forecasts generated fitted EpiEstim model returned quantiles (2.5%, 25%, 50%, 75%, 97.5%), minimum, maximum.

title: Forecast daily epidemic cases using EpiEstim ‚Äî generate_forecast
code: # Create sample test rsv data disease_type <- "rsv" test_data <- simulate_data() formatted_data <- get_aggregated_data(   test_data,   number_column = disease_type,   date_column = "date",   start_date = "2024-04-01",   end_date = "2024-05-01" )  # Run a 7 day forecast with smoothing res_smooth <- generate_forecast(   data = formatted_data,   start_date = "2024-04-01",   n_days = 7,   type = "rsv",   smooth_data = FALSE )

what: Generate Viral Respiratory Forecast Report ‚Äî generate_forecast_report
title: Generate Viral Respiratory Forecast Report ‚Äî generate_forecast_report
text: Generates full-season forecast report viral respiratory diseases HTML document.

title: Generate Viral Respiratory Forecast Report ‚Äî generate_forecast_report
code: generate_forecast_report(   input_data_dir = NULL,   output_dir = NULL,   n_days = 7,   validate_window_size = 7,   smooth = FALSE,   disease_season = NULL )

title: Generate Viral Respiratory Forecast Report ‚Äî generate_forecast_report
text: input_data_dir Path input CSV data. Must contain columns: date, confirm, disease_type. Allowed values disease_type: "flu_a", "flu_b", "rsv", "sars_cov2", "custom". output_dir Path output directory rendered HTML report. n_days Number days ahead forecast. Default 7. validate_window_size number days validation window. Default 7. smooth Logical indicating whether smoothing applied forecast. Default TRUE. disease_season optional named list specifying seasonal date ranges disease. element either: NULL (indicating defined season), two-date vector "YY-MM-DD" format (e.g., c("2024-09-01", "2025-03-01")) defining start end season disease. example: disease_season = list( flu_a     = c("2024-09-01", "2025-03-01"), rsv       = c("2024-09-01", "2025-03-01"), sars_cov2 = NULL ) produce report influenza RSV seasons run September 1, 2024 March 1, 2025, season defined SARS-CoV-2.

title: Generate Viral Respiratory Forecast Report ‚Äî generate_forecast_report
text: Invisibly returns path rendered HTML report.

title: Generate Viral Respiratory Forecast Report ‚Äî generate_forecast_report
code: # \donttest{ data <- simulate_data(start_date = "2024-01-07", #starting Sunday ) diseases <- c("flu_a", "rsv", "sars_cov2") data$date <- lubridate::ymd(data$date) vri_data_list <- purrr::set_names( purrr::map2( rep(list(data), length(diseases)),                                   diseases,                                   ~ get_aggregated_data(.x, "date", .y)                                  ),                             diseases ) # Save the simulated data df <- purrr::imap_dfr( vri_data_list, \(df, disease) dplyr::mutate(df, disease_type = disease) ) tmp_dir <- tempdir() # temporary directory for example for saving data data_path <- file.path(tmp_dir, "simulated_data.csv") write.csv(df, data_path, row.names = FALSE)  output_path <- tempdir() # output directory for report (temporary as example) generate_forecast_report(input_data_dir = data_path,                          output_dir = output_path,                          n_days = 7,                          validate_window_size = 7,                          smooth = FALSE) #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpWuLDzf/vriforecasting_report.html" # }

what: Validate forecast performance over multiple time windows ‚Äî generate_validation
title: Validate forecast performance over multiple time windows ‚Äî generate_validation
text: function performs rolling validation short-term forecasts generated EpiEstim similar models. divides input time series overlapping validation windows repeatedly runs forecasts assess model performance across different time segments.

title: Validate forecast performance over multiple time windows ‚Äî generate_validation
code: generate_validation(   data,   start_date,   validate_window_size = 7,   window_size = 7,   n_days = 7,   type = NULL,   smooth_data = FALSE,   smoothing_cutoff = 10,   ... )

title: Validate forecast performance over multiple time windows ‚Äî generate_validation
text: data data frame containing least columns "date" "confirm". "date" column class Date, "confirm" numeric. start_date Date (date-convertible string) specifying starting point validation Must exist "date" column. validate_window_size Integer. number days validation window (default: 7). window_size Integer. sliding window size (days) used forecasting model (default: 7). n_days Integer. number future days forecast validation iteration (default: 7). type character Type epidemic. Must one "flu_a", "flu_b", "rsv", "sars_cov2", "custom". Passed fit_epiestim_model. smooth_data Logical. Whether smooth input case counts prior forecasting (default: FALSE). smoothing_cutoff Numeric. Threshold used smoothing smooth_data = TRUE (default: 10). ... Additional arguments passed generate_forecast().

title: Validate forecast performance over multiple time windows ‚Äî generate_validation
text: list forecast results, element corresponding one validation window. element contains output returned generate_forecast() particular window.

title: Validate forecast performance over multiple time windows ‚Äî generate_validation
text: validation procedure ensures forecasts evaluated realistic temporal conditions. Starting earliest date, function repeatedly: Takes growing subset data current validation endpoint. Runs forecast using generate_forecast(). Moves validation window forward validate_window_size days. results set forecasts can compared observed data evaluate predictive performance across time.

title: Validate forecast performance over multiple time windows ‚Äî generate_validation
code: data <- simulate_data() formatted_data <- get_aggregated_data(data,"date", "flu_a", "2024-10-16", "2024-12-31") start_date <- as.Date("2024-10-16") validation_results <- generate_validation(formatted_data, start_date, type="flu_a")

what: Compute Forecast Validation Metrics (SMAPE & MASE) ‚Äî generate_validation_metric
title: Compute Forecast Validation Metrics (SMAPE & MASE) ‚Äî generate_validation_metric
text: function evaluates forecast accuracy across multiple validation runs computing two key performance metrics:

title: Compute Forecast Validation Metrics (SMAPE & MASE) ‚Äî generate_validation_metric
code: generate_validation_metric(data, validation_res)

title: Compute Forecast Validation Metrics (SMAPE & MASE) ‚Äî generate_validation_metric
text: data data frame used generate_validation(), containing original training data model. must include: date: Dates observed case data (class Date). confirm: Numeric values observed confirmed cases. validation_res list forecast validation results, typically output generate_validation(). element contain: forecast_res_quantiles: data frame columns date p50 (median forecasted values). original_data: data frame representing training data used forecast, date column.

title: Compute Forecast Validation Metrics (SMAPE & MASE) ‚Äî generate_validation_metric
text: tibble (data frame) one row per forecast result following columns: train_period: Date range training period used forecast. forecast_period: Date range forecasted period. smape: Symmetric Mean Absolute Percentage Error forecasted actual values, rounded two decimals. mase: Mean Absolute Scaled Error, rounded two decimals.

title: Compute Forecast Validation Metrics (SMAPE & MASE) ‚Äî generate_validation_metric
text: Symmetric Mean Absolute Percentage Error (SMAPE): Measures relative forecast accuracy remaining robust zero values actual data. Mean Absolute Scaled Error (MASE): Scales forecast errors relative -sample one-step na√Øve forecast, allowing comparison across series different scales. forecast result, function also reports corresponding training forecast periods. Computation stops forecast period reaches maximum date model data. SMAPE defined : $$SMAPE = mean( |F - | / ((|| + |F|) / 2) )$$ \(\) actual values \(F\) forecasts. avoids division zero suitable count data zeros. MASE compares mean absolute forecast error mean absolute difference successive actual: $$MASE = mean(|- F|) / mean(|diff()|)$$ function automatically excludes forecasts extending beyond latest date observed model data.

title: Compute Forecast Validation Metrics (SMAPE & MASE) ‚Äî generate_validation_metric

what: Extract Aggregated Weekly Generic Data ‚Äî get_aggregated_data
title: Extract Aggregated Weekly Generic Data ‚Äî get_aggregated_data
text: get_aggregated_data() performs data transformation following steps: Group weekly daily data date. Aggregate number confirmed cases either day week. Select date confirmed cases column. Filter data given start end date input dataframe generic_data must following columns: <date name>: date column (e.g. .Date('2022-01-01')). <cases count name>: Confirmed Cases Count (e.g. 1, 2, ...). Note columns can defined generic name, inputted two function parameters data transformation (date_column, number_column) Assume date column start epiweek.

title: Extract Aggregated Weekly Generic Data ‚Äî get_aggregated_data
code: get_aggregated_data(   generic_data,   date_column,   number_column,   start_date = NULL,   end_date = NULL,   unit = "day" )

title: Extract Aggregated Weekly Generic Data ‚Äî get_aggregated_data
text: generic_data weekly generic data get_data() date_column date column name str number_column cases count column name str start_date start date string (e.g. '2022-01-01')(optional, default NULL) end_date end date string (e.g. '2022-12-31')(optional, default NULL) unit aggregation unit "day" "week"

title: Extract Aggregated Weekly Generic Data ‚Äî get_aggregated_data
text: aggregated weekly data generic confirmed cases data (filtered date ) date Either day week date confirm number confirmed cases

text: function deprecated may removed future release. function creates ggplot comparing estimated reproduction numbers (\(R\)) time multiple EpiEstim outputs. input named object produced EpiEstim containing estimate_R$R data frame.

title: Compare Reproduction Number Estimates from Multiple EpiEstim Outputs ‚Äî plot_R_fit_comparison
code: plot_R_fit_comparison(...)

title: Compare Reproduction Number Estimates from Multiple EpiEstim Outputs ‚Äî plot_R_fit_comparison
text: ... Named EpiEstim output objects produced generate_forecast(). object contain data frame estimate_R$R columns : t_start, t_end: Time window indices Median(R): Median estimated reproduction number Quantile.0.025(R) / Quantile.0.975(R): 95% credible interval bounds Quantile.0.25(R) / Quantile.0.75(R): 50% credible interval bounds

title: Compare Reproduction Number Estimates from Multiple EpiEstim Outputs ‚Äî plot_R_fit_comparison
text: ggplot2 object showing median \(R\) estimates 50% 95% credible intervals, colored input source (.e., name).

title: Compare Forecast Outputs ‚Äî plot_forecast_comparison

title: Compare Forecast Outputs ‚Äî plot_forecast_comparison
text: ggplot2 object showing forecasted median incidences time shaded prediction intervals, colored input source (.e., model name).

title: Plot a ribbon plot with each time horizon predictions against true values for validation ‚Äî plot_validation
text: data data frame used generate_validation(), containing original training data used model fitting. Must include: date: Dates observed data (class Date). confirm: Numeric values confirmed cases. validation_res list forecast validation results, typically produced generate_validation(). element include: forecast_res_quantiles: data frame containing forecasted quantiles (p025, p10, p25, p50, p75, p90, p975, date). estimate_R: list estimated reproduction numbers (used grouping). smoothed_data: (optional) data frame smoothed observations, smoothing applied forecasting. pred_plot either "ribbon" "error_bar" (default) produce either ribbon prediction plots error_bar plots respectively

what: Simulate Daily Virus Incidence Data ‚Äî simulate_data
title: Simulate Daily Virus Incidence Data ‚Äî simulate_data
text: Generates simulated daily incidence data specified respiratory viruses defined number days. virus modeled using Gaussian-like curve, parameterized peak day, amplitude, scale.

title: Simulate Daily Virus Incidence Data ‚Äî simulate_data
code: simulate_data(   days = 365,   peaks = c(flu_a = 90, rsv = 110, sars_cov2 = 160),   amplitudes = c(flu_a = 50, rsv = 40, sars_cov2 = 20),   scales = c(flu_a = -0.004, rsv = -0.005, sars_cov2 = -0.001),   time_offset = 0,   noise_sd = 5,   start_date = "2024-01-07" )

title: Simulate Daily Virus Incidence Data ‚Äî simulate_data
text: days Integer. Number days simulate (default 365). peaks Named numeric vector. Peak day virus (e.g., c("flua"=90,"rsv"=110,"sars_cov2"=160)). amplitudes Named numeric vector. Amplitude virus's peak (e.g., c("flua"=50,"rsv"=40,"sars_cov2"=20)). scales Named numeric vector. Scale controlling spread peak virus (e.g., c("flua"=-0.004,"rsv"=-0.005,"sars_cov2"=-0.001)). time_offset Integer. Number days offset start simulation. useful want test data larger values middle respiratory season. noise_sd numeric named numeric. Gaussian noise applied virus signal. can either single value named virus e.g., c("flu_a"=2,"rsv"=5,"sars_cov2"=7) start_date string

title: Simulate Daily Virus Incidence Data ‚Äî simulate_data
text: data frame daily simulated incidence counts virus, including date column.
